clinical_study.brief_title: PWV for Cardiovascular Complication After Cardiac Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Pulse Wave Velocity as a Predictive Factor for Postoperative Cardiovascular Complication After Cardiac Surgery: a Prospective Study

brief_summary.textblock: Arterial stiffness has been suggested as an independent risk factor for the development of coronary artery disease and stroke. Pulse wave velocity (PWV) is an noninvasive established index to quantify arterial stiffness. Therefore, we try to investigate the correlation between PWV values and cardiovascular complications like stroke, acute renal failure, or perioperative myocardial infarction after cardiac surgery.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.measure: Perioperative myocardial infarction (Measurement of CKMB, Troponin I, and new Q wave in EKG)
primary_outcome.description: CK-MB> 10 times the upper normal limit or 5 times the upper normal limit plus new Q waves when 24 hours after operation, New Q waves in two or more contiguous leads, or new LBBB on ECG; Troponin I levels >20 ug/L within 12 hours and >35ug/L at 24 hours
neurologic symptoms like paralysis, speech impairment, loss of memory and reasoning ability, and coma confirmed by neurologists with or without neurologic imaging evidences
serum creatinine to >2.0mg/dL and to twice the preoperative level (defined by 2004 STS database specifications)

primary_outcome.time_frame: Preoperative PWV should be measured 30 days or less before operation

primary_outcome.description: baPWV should be rechecked at least 1 month after the operation to investigate whether PWV will be improved or not after the cardiac surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Cardiac surgery patients who sign the informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Chronic renal failure (Cr>1.5mg/dL), Dialysis patients
- Previous stroke
- Left ventricular dysfunction (EF <50%)
- ASO with claudication
- < 40 years
